Calling the app secret a "secret" is an unfortunate side-effect of using OAuth 1.0. The "secret" isn't really secret in applications that must client-side, such as mobile apps, desktop apps, and JavaScript apps without backends.

The Dropbox authentication model doesn't assume that the secret is actually secret. The user must approve every request to `/oauth/authorize`, which is different from Facebook's OAuth 2.0 model.

In the future, I hope there will be better messaging around the API key and "secret". Until then, please write awesome JavaScript apps!

Last but not least, if there are any authentication improvements in the REST API, and I'm not on top of them, please file a bug!

No idea how the garbled comment got there, sorry. In any case, you can use [localStorage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/DOM/Storage) to store your user's credentials.

The `credentials` method in `Dropbox.Client` will give you a JSON-compliant object that you can save into localStorage using something like `localStorage.setItem('dropbox_auth', JSON.stringify(client.credentials()))`. Later, pass this object to the `Dropbox.Client` constructor to pick up from where you left, using something along the lines of `new Dropbox.Client(JSON.parse(localStorge.getItem('dropbox_auth')))`.

As a warning, once you do that, you have to come up with a strategy for dealing with expired tokens. That's the main reason why the sample apps don't store user tokens -- I didn't want the expiration logic code to get readers confused.

Hey, guys!

Sorry, having to authorize every time is a pain indeed. Most of the reasons why the drivers don't store the OAuth tokens for you are historical (solved bugs), but there is one real issue left -- if you store the OAuth tokens, the user isn't "logged out" of your application when they log out of Dropbox.

As a workaround until I figure out a better way of logging out, set the `rememberUser: true` option when instantiating the `Dropbox.Driver.Redirect` OAuth driver.

``` javascript
client.authDriver(new Dropbox.Drivers.Redirect({rememberUser: true}));
```

This should do the trick in development. If you really want to push this to real users, at the very least have a "Sign out" button somewhere, and call `forgetCredentials()` on the OAuth driver.

Sorry, I forgot to mention, you'll need to build `dropbox.js` off of GitHub to use `rememberUser`.

The credentials should not contain `authState`. The object returned by `credentials()` only has the `authState` property set during the authentication process. After the authentication succeeds, the `credentials()` object should have the following properties: `key`, `secret`, `sandbox`, `token`, `tokenSecret` and `uid`.

This test backs up what I just said.
https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-js/blob/master/test/src/client_test.coffee#L619

Made a couple of improvements.
- the "Sign out" implementation should call `signOut` on the `Dropbox.Client`, instead of calling some obscure method on the OAuth driver.
- the `checkbox.js` sample app in the repository has been updated to use `rememberUser`, and has a "Sign out" implementation
- there is some documentation for [writing OAuth drivers](https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-js/blob/master/doc/auth_drivers.md)
- everything will be available in dropbox.js 0.6.0, which should hit up `cdnjs` pretty soon

Also, if you use the `rememberUser` option for the `Dropbox.Drivers.Redirect` driver in dropbox.js 0.6.0, you can call `authenticate` on every page, and the user won't see confirmation dialogs, since `localStorage` is shared by pages with the same origin. I hope this helps.

After a conversation with Dropboxers on the API team, we decided to add support to `dropbox.js` for concealing the API key and secret, and to require that browser-side applications use this method (or any other method) to conceal their API credentials before applying for production status.

The details are [here](https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-js/blob/master/doc/getting_started.md#browser-and-open-source-applications).

I tried to make the process as painless as possible. Please file a bug if you think of a way to further streamline this.
This fix was included in `dropbox.js` version 0.6.1.

@martinklein Sorry, the documentation must be confusing. I'll try to explain. If my explanation makes sense, please consider sending a pull request with a documentation fix.

There are two types of files in your application, the source code, and the application data.

The _source code_ lives in `Apps/Static Web Apps/DVD Library` in _your_ Dropbox, and is publicly available at the URL generated by the [Static Web Apps console](https://dl-web.dropbox.com/spa/pjlfdak1tmznswp/powered_by.js/public/index.html). You can think of this location as a file server. For example, this is where you should put the HTML, CSS, JavaScript and images behind your application.

The _application data_ lives in `Apps/DVD Library` in _each of your users'_ Dropboxes. This is the area that you can access via `readFile` and `writeFile` calls. The tricky concept here is that each user's data is stored in their Dropbox, so you can only see your own data. On the bright side, you can get security for free, as long as you don't store your users' credentials in a central place.

The OAuth implementation in the Dropbox API requires the API key and API secret for making API calls. So `Dropbox.Client` needs the `key` parameter. It could definitely throw a more descriptive error message though, I'll see what I can do about that.

Hello.

I use [Spring Social library](https://github.com/SpringSource/spring-net-social-dropbox) for .NET. And its implementation allows to get access token once and then use it for any future requests without using App key/secret.
According to [dropbox API documentation](https://www.dropbox.com/developers/start/authentication#python) 

> The access token is all you'll need for all future API requests on behalf of this user, so you should store it away for safe-keeping. By storing the access token, you won't need to go through these steps again unless the user reinstalls your app or revokes access via the Dropbox website.

Could you please confirm if I'm wrong and I should always use app key?

Thank you.

The text in the dropbox API documentation is a bit unfortunate, but its meaning is that once you have an access token, you don't need to obtain a request token, authenticate it, and exchange it for the access token.

The [REST API reference](https://www.dropbox.com/developers/reference/api), which documents the HTTP protocol that all the other SDKs are built on top of, says "Dropbox uses OAuth to authenticate all API requests."

The [OAuth 1.0a example](http://oauth.net/core/1.0a/#anchor46) shows that the API key needs to be passed in as the `oauth_consumer_key` parameter, and the API secret is used to compute the `oauth_signature` field.

Last, the [example](http://www.springframework.net/social-dropbox/refdoc/api.html) provided as an API reference by the library that you mentioned seems to contradict your claims that it doesn't need an API key / secret. The `serviceProvider` variable holds an instance of `DropboxServiceProvider`, whose constructor takes in an API key and secret. The library seems to require a `IDropbox` instance to make actual API calls, and the provided example uses a call on `serviceProvider` to get an `IDropbox` instance. So the `IDropbox` instance does get the API key and secret.

I hope this helps!

`long` is not listed as a reserved word in JavaScript.
http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-7.6.1
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/JavaScript/Reference/Reserved_Words

Furtheremore, it says reserved words are only relevant when it comes to identifiers. Using `long` as a property name should be fine.

I looked into the source code, and filed a bug with the Rhino project.
https://github.com/mozilla/rhino/issues/93

Until I fix the documentation, here are some pointers.

We tested `writeFile` with Blob instances.
https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-js/blob/master/test/src/client_test.coffee#L33

However, `writeFile` uses XHR, so it should be able to take ArrayBuffer instances, etc.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/DOM/XMLHttpRequest

HTML5Rocks has a good tutorial on reading local files into Blob instances.
http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/file/dndfiles/
http://www.html5rocks.com/en/features/file_access

Keep in mind that you can't read arbitrary files off the user's filesystem. You need to make users select the files in an `<input type="file">` control, or drag-and-drop them into your application.

@code Please beware of #30 though (I know you'll bump into it, because ID3 tags are at the end of a file). You'll have to compute `start` based on the file length in the metadata.

@piranna I do default `length` to the file length minus `start` (if specified). However, if `length` is specified, I default `start` to the file length minus `length`, because that's how HTTP ranges work, and because I think this is more useful. For example, if you want to read the last few kilobytes from a file, to scan for ID3 tags, the default I mentioned lets you do that without having to fetch the file's metadata. I hope specifying `start: 0` isn't too much of a pain, in return for having support for end-of-file reads.

I think seeking would make sense in a higher-level API. I wanted to build a higher-level API that would come with built-in caching and object-oriented representations of files and folders, and I saved the `Dropbox` namespace for that. However, I didn't have time to make it happen, and I doubt this will happen anytime soon :(

Take a look at filer.js, is a high level API for Filesystem API with read,
write, seek and touch functions in a similar way of OS system calls. I
think it should be fairly easy to adapt it to dropbox.js.

Also, although Filesystem API is pseudo-deprecated (Mozilla don't like it
in benefict of IndexedDB) it could be a good inspiration for dropbox.js API
and also would allow some compatibility and interoperability (Filesystem
API specify a per web page isolated filesystem on the user agent, and
dropbox.js is more or less like this :-D).

@piranna I don't really like filer.js, because it makes up its own API. I agree that most old-school Unix developers (myself included) will recognize the commands right away, but I have yet to be convinced that most of today's Web developers fall in that category.

dropbox.js roughly follows the node.js API for file access, so at least node.js developers should be familiar with it.

On the other hand, the Filesystem API is indeed something to look at! If the API doesn't get killed by Mozilla's refusal to implement it, it's worth providing a compatibility layer for it. Then higher-level libraries like filer.js can use that layer and just work.

Does this seem reasonable?

Thank you for your feedback, Michiel!

The Dropbox API uses the OAuth1 model that has the client app establish a request token, get the user to authorize the token, and then exchange the request token for an access token.

If I understand OAuth2 implicit grant correctly, it is a bit different: the user is sent to an authorization page, and then an access token is generated. This flow is much better suited for browser apps, and in an ideal world, dropbox.js would use this flow to get a token from the Dropbox API server.

Unfortunately, the API server only supports OAuth 1 at the moment, so dropbox.js implements that, and tries to insulate developers from the complexities and present an OAuth2-like interface. I will take your feedback as a sign that I'm succeeding at insulating :)
Does this seem reasonable? If I'm missing something from the OAuth specs, please let me know!

@nathanathan, thank you for your feedback!

I agree that sync support would be nice to have! I looked into this in early January, and here are my findings:
- IndexedDB is the way to go; the FileSystem API is Chrome-only, and the Firefox devs said they will not implement it
- Chrome's IndexedDB implementation doesn't handle blobs yet, so the blob contents has to be turned into binary Strings (on Chrome-only)
- Chrome's IndexedDB implementation crashes on large strings, so files have to be broken up into blocks; this is probably a good idea anyway
- Chrome crashes when trying to handle blobs that have 1Gb or more data, so the sync code should use ranged reads (that's probably a good idea for large reads anyway)

I explored this in my Chrome extension for downloading files to Dropbox. These bits might be reusable:
- IndexedDB wrapper: https://github.com/pwnall/dropship-chrome/blob/master/src/coffee/dropship_list.coffee
- Uploading code that works well with both large and small files: https://github.com/pwnall/dropship-chrome/blob/master/src/coffee/upload_controller.coffee

I started working on some sync infrastructure in a branch, but I decided to prioritize making dropbox.js not suck in node.js. I hope I'll have time to revisit this.

Thanks Victor! There are a couple things I wanted to point out:
-  Cordova and most mobile browsers do not yet support IndexedDB. However, there is a [polyfill](http://blog.nparashuram.com/2012/10/indexeddb-example-on-cordova-phonegap_12.html). There's also a [polyfill](http://ericbidelman.tumblr.com/post/21649963613/idb-filesystem-js-bringing-the-html5-filesystem-api) to add filesystem support to IndexedDB browsers.
-  With IndexedDB it seems like it would be harder for multiple applications to share data. On android the Cordova file system API allows you to read/write almost anywhere on the sdcard. (One of the neat tricks this allows is file syncing via [DropSync](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.ttxapps.dropsync&feature=search_result#?t=W251bGwsMSwxLDEsImNvbS50dHhhcHBzLmRyb3BzeW5jIl0). It's not a perfect solution. I'd rather be able to launch syncs at specific points in time from within my app and perhaps have some custom code for resolving conflicts.)

https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-js/issues/19#issuecomment-13117737

When the user gets redirected back to your application, your page's state is completely reloaded. This means your code has to distinguish between the case when the user visits your page for the first time, and the case where they come back from the redirect.

The `interactive: false` option in the `authenticate()` method does that for you. So, if the user has authorized your app, you can start making API calls. If the user hasn't authorized your app, you need to call the authorize a 2nd time when they click the button, to start the redirect process. This is why two authorize calls are necessary.

I'm not sure how to simplify this. The authentication process requires HTTP calls before and after the redirect, so I need you to call some method that allows dropbox.js to do the HTTP call, and that gives it a callback to report to.

`rememberUser` is not well-named. I'll most likely change the API in soon. This feedback https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-js/issues/45#issuecomment-13708661 made me start thinking, as I agree with the pain points.

Until then, `rememberUser: true` is basically "I promise I have a button that calls signOut / signOff." localStorage is used all the time in the Redirect driver. When `rememberUser` is false, the OAuth access token is not stored in localStorage, so the OAuth redirect flow happens every time users visit your app's page(s). When `rememberUser` is true, the OAuth access token is stored and reused when users re-visit your app. The problem with this is that there's no _obvious_ way for the user to revoke the credentials, e.g. when leaving a shared computer, so apps have to opt into this behavior.

When `rememberUser` is true, dropbox.js makes a `getUserInfo` to check whether cached tokens are still valid, because I don't want to tell the app that the user is signed-in, and then force it to go through an auth flow right away. Assuming no bugs in dropbox.js, you should only see one network request to `/account/info`. https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-js/blob/1a53562f17e7f3e69af6a2ab56e938b62f3c1b96/src/drivers/browser.coffee#L53

Hi, Jake!

Right now, the answer is "maybe".

Files: you can use downloadable URLs to share files without authentication. Use `downloadHack` in `client.makeUrl` to get a downloadable link.
http://coffeedoc.info/github/dropbox/dropbox-js/master/classes/Dropbox/Client.html#makeUrl-instance

Directories: there's no API for downloading an entire directory right now. You can scrape the preview page for the 'download zip' URL, but that's brittle. If your application also creates the public data, you can put together a JSON file with `downloadHack` URLs to all the files in a directory, and use the URL for that file, instead of using the directory's URL.

Does this help at all?

Can you try adding the following section to your `cache.manifest`?

```
NETWORK:
*
```

@glynthomas Signing off disables the access token :)

signOff / signOut is supposed to be called when the user intends to "sign off" from your application. This means they might be leaving a shared computer, and the computer's next user should not be able to access their data. Given all possible ways in which applications could store tokens, the only correct way of implementing "sign off" is to invalidate the token.

On your end, you should delete the token from localStorage, and/or any other browser-side place that stores it. Next time the user accesses your application, they should log back in.

On the other hand, if you're only using dropbox.js on the server side (e.g., in node.js), and the user's Dropbox token never leaves your server, you can rely on your own session management code for logging out users, and you can use a Dropbox token until it expires. In that case, you shouldn't call signOff / signOut on Dropbox.Client.

If the token is stored on the client side, you should revoke it when the user signs out, and get a new one when the user comes back and signs in. Leaving a valid token in the user's browser cache or localStorage would definitely not meet the expectation of being logged out, and your app might get disabled if someone notices that and complains.

If your app is completely client-side, I see two solutions:
1. Use Dropbox for your authentication, like the samples do.
2. If you want to use another server, have it store the user's Dropbox token, and get it when the user is authenticated. Or you can have the server generate a per-user encryption key, and use that to store the Dropbox token in an encrypted form on the client side.

I was able to work around this problem by doing a binary read using the {arrayBuffer: true} option on readFile.  This allowed me to get the bytes of the file directly before any sort of charset interpretation.  I was then able to build a string from those bytes and decode it from the UTF-8 encoding it was transported in.  The end result was the string I had originally written properly encoded.

Hey, @dwiyatci!

Sorry, dropbox.js does not currently support synchronous calls.

First off, dropbox.js relies on XMLHttpRequest, which was designed for asynchronous use. Using it in a synchronous manner would block the UI thread until the HTTP request completes, which is really bad for the users. On fast Internet connections, a Dropbox API call takes hundreds of milliseconds, so doing a few of those head-to-head means your application's tab would be completely unresponsive for seconds at a time. Most users would think something is wrong with your site, and outright close your tab!

Second, XMLHttpRequest discourages synchronous use, so some of its modern features (e.g. binary files) are not supported when the library is used synchronously. This means our code and documentation would have to become more complicated to support synchronous calling, which would mostly negate the simplicity advantages of the synchronous call model.

Sorry for the bad news!

On the bright side, there are some JavaScript libraries that can help you get up to speed quickly on asynchronous programming. I strongly recommend [async.js](https://github.com/caolan/async/). Tutorials such as the [html5rocks one](http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/async/deferred/) might help as well. If you can afford spending some money (or your company reimburses books) I also recommend [Pragmatic Programmer's book on async JavaScript](http://pragprog.com/book/tbajs/async-javascript).

I might revisit this issue over the summer. I think synchronous XHR would make it easier to learn how to use the library, and might help with debugging. Even if I end up working on it, putting together synchronous tests will take up some time, so please don't block waiting for this to happen!

After doing some research I've discovered how Firefox OS currently does OAuth flows. For example here in [parameters.js](https://github.com/mozilla-b2g/gaia/blob/master/apps/communications/contacts/oauth2/js/parameters.js#L18), which is a part of the current Contacts app. The Contacts app has a way of syncing your Facebook contacts with Firefox OS. You'll see that there are external redirect endpoints defined, which are basically landing pages. Though I did try to redirect to local resources, there are security policies that will not let you do that. So it seems like if the Contacts app could not do it, it might not be possible or secure enough. I got a nice **dropbox-js** flow working on Firefox OS using an external endpoint just like the Contacts app: **main.js** (your app) ``` javascript var client = new Dropbox.Client({ key: "KEY_HERE", sandbox: true }); client.authDriver(new Dropbox.Drivers.Popup({ rememberUser: true, receiverUrl: "http://EXAMPLE.com/oauth_receiver.html" })); ``` **oauth_receiver.html** (hosted somewhere else) ``` html

Dropbox sign-in successful

Great, so you confirm that exposing secret key doesn't compromise the security of the application in any way?

@adnandoric That is not what I said.

First off, you should never expose your API key and secret in plaintext in an application. You should make some decent effort to obfuscate it, so a casual attacker can't lift the API key and secret and impersonate your application. dropbox.js has build-in obfuscation support, and the link above documents setting it up.

Second, this isn't a perfect solution. It is the best we can do for applications that need to run the OAuth flow client-side. If you're worried about security, you should use dropbox.js in node.js or another server environment, so credentials aren't exposed to clients.

We'll have a better client-side story really, really soon.

dropbox.js is layered on top of an XMLHttpRequest emulation in node.js because I wanted to maximize code sharing across platforms. I'm worried that having separate code paths for node.js will make it more likely that bugs will go undetected.

That being said, if I am shown that XMLHttpRequest emulation layer has an impact on performance, I will reconsider the design.

If the only perf issue is streaming, I think that the best solution would be to implement the W3C streaming proposal in [node.xhr2](https://github.com/pwnall/node-xhr2) and add a `stream` option to `readFile`.
https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/streams-api/raw-file/tip/Overview.htm

That's too bad. OAuth1 allowed http redirection (works fine with version 0.9.2) by passing the token after the hash mark in the URL so that it's not transmitted to any server. Is there any way to use the old OAuth1 authentication with latest version 0.10.1?

@benweet If you serve your page over plain http, an adversary can do a man-in-the-middle attack and inject JavaScript that leaks the token your page receives. Unfortunately, just because the fragment isn't sent to the server, that doesn't make a Web app served over http secure. Because of this issue, we decided to disallow "http" completely in OAuth 2.

OAuth 1 will be deprecated, and I expect that it will not be supported in a future version of the API.

I personally recommend taking a look at [StartSSL](http://www.startssl.com/). Their UI is not great to say the least, but they do offer free SSL certificates, so you can get https for your site.

TL;DR: the libraries can share the namespace. For best results, load dropbox.js last.

This should work. Please file bugs if it doesn't. We have an informal agreement on dividing the Dropbox namespace, so no naming conflicts should ever happen.

dropbox.js has a bit of special code that makes sure it will coexist with the saver JS, as long as dropbox.js is loaded last. If dropbox.js is loaded first, the saver would have to take similar precautions to make sure both libraries will share the Dropbox namespace, and I don't have a test for that case.

To the best of my knowledge, the Saver renders that nice UI server-side. I would like to have something similar available for dropbox.js, either in the core library or as a sibling project, but it's non-trivial, and I don't have the time to do it right now.

Also, dropbox.js requires a different API key, authorization, and production approval, so you'll have to do some mental juggling if you use both in the same application.

@iangilman At the moment, `writeFile` uses [files_put](https://www.dropbox.com/developers/core/docs#files_put) or `files [POST]`(https://www.dropbox.com/developers/core/docs#files-POST), depending on the browser. `resumableUploadStep` and `resumableUploadFinish` use chunked uploads, if you need to go above 150MB. It would be nice to have `writeFile` automatically use resumableUpload when necessary, so please open an issue if you run into this problem.

No, this isn't stored in the browser anywhere. This is on the Dropbox side... Dropbox sees that your account is already linked to the app and just redirects you immediately.

So what happens is each time you link the app with your account, a new access token is generated. Calling `signoff` disables the access token currently used but doesn't do anything about the other tokens. As long as you still have at least one valid access token for the app, you'll get the automatic redirect behavior.

You can fully unlink your account from the app by visiting https://www.dropbox.com/account/security and clicking the X next to the app. If you then link the app and then use `signoff`, you should be forced to allow the app access again the next time you try to auth. (This is because you only had one access token, and `signoff` disabled that token.)

You can also pass `force_reapprove=true` as part of your OAuth 2 redirect to always force the user to approve the app again, even if they already have. I don't think the JS SDK exposes this parameter, but it shouldn't be hard to add.

I think `POST` is also supported, and browsers have better support for `POST` than `PUT`.

I went for `POST` because it's less likely to trigger a CORS preflight request. Preflights are evil because they delay the main request by a full round-trip, so there's quite a bit of logic in dropbox.js for avoiding them whenever possible.

I think chunked uploading still triggers CORS preflights, but using a `POST` gets us one step closer to getting rid of them.

Do you mean that you always want to use _your_ account (instead of the app user's account)? If so, you _could_ pass an access token when you construct your client object:

```
new Dropbox.Client({ token: '<YOUR ACCESS TOKEN>' });
```

However, this is **not** recommended for a few reasons. Most importantly, every user of your app would be able to take this access token and delete all your files, upload their own private DVD collection, etc. Essentially, anyone who has access to your app now has access to your Dropbox account.

The typical model for the Dropbox API is for each user of an app to access his or her own account.

You seem to be confused about how XMLHttpRequest event listeners work. Either you assign a function to a DOM0-style property, like "onprogress", or you call the DOM2 addEventListener.

addEventListener is almost always better, because you can add multiple listeners from different parts of your code. Specifically:

``` javascript
dbXhr.xhr.upload.addEventListener("progress", function(event) { ... })
```

Yup just spent a few hours relearning this. The problem is that during chromium packaged app development if you don't have a key in your manifest.json file the packaged app's ID can change, it will be automatically generated by Chrome when the app is loaded. You can find details on Stack Overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21497781/how-to-change-chrome-packaged-app-id-or-why-do-we-need-key-field-in-the-manifest. If you decide to let the ID change then every time it does you will have to update the OAuth callback URLs in your Dropbox app's OAuth2 Settings to match the new ID. For example:
https://[your app id].chromiumapp.org/

Anyway "Authorization page could not be loaded." is a symptom of not configuring Dropbox with the correct OAuth 2 callback URL. Just thought anyone arriving here via search might like to know.

Hello all,

I would really love to see these changes merged so I decided to take a look at this PR. 

@ehfeng The error you're getting is a failing test because there are still some issues with the optional parameters logic. The first issue is that a cursor can be a string (which is used in the "with a bad cursor" test and is described in the documentation above the method). The second is that in your current PR, the last `else if` can never be executed because it is strictly more restrictive than the preceding `else if`. I think the following is a better approach for checking the optional parameters and works with the existing tests:

``` coffeescript
# Returns if a parameter was a cursor or not
isCursor = (param) ->
  (typeof param is 'object' and param.cursorTag) or typeof param is 'string'

if (not options) and (not callback) and (typeof cursor is 'function')
  callback = cursor
  cursor = null
  options = null
# if options were not passed but cursor was passed
else if (not callback) and (typeof options is 'function') and isCursor(cursor)
  callback = options
  options = null
# if cursor was not passed but options were passed
else if (not callback) and (typeof options is 'function') and not isCursor(cursor)
  callback = options
  cursor = null
  options = cursor
```

I also am a little confused as to why you were allowing the options to be passed in from the cursor object or the options object. I suppose it could simplify subsequent calls to the pullChanges function (by not having to pass in options) but I'm not sure you really gain anything from that. In the diff below I took this out (as well as the storing of options in pullChanges) because you weren't passing these options into the parse method anyway (line 1128 of client.coffee).

If you're not interested in working on this anymore @ehfeng I don't mind writing some tests to make sure this works. Really looking forward to these changes!

I wrote an auth driver that seems to work for me using nw.js:

``` coffee
gui = global.window.nwDispatcher.requireNwGui()

class Dropbox.AuthDriver.NWAuthDriver extends Dropbox.AuthDriver.BrowserBase
  constructor: (options) ->
    super options

  url: ->
    'https://www.dropbox.com/1/oauth2/redirect_receiver'

  doAuthorize: (authUrl, stateParam, client, callback) ->
    popup = gui.Window.open authUrl, { focus: true }
    removed = false
    popup.on 'loaded', =>
        url = popup.window.location.href
        if @locationStateParam(url) is stateParam
            return if removed
            removed = true
            popup.close()

            callback Dropbox.Util.Oauth.queryParamsFromUrl(url)
            return
    popup.on 'closed', =>
        return if removed
        callback new Dropbox.AuthError('error=access_denied&error_description=User+closed+browser+window')
        return
```

I put that in a file called NWAuthDriver.coffee, compiled it to NWAuthDriver.js, and then just included it in a `<script>` tag under `dropbox.js` itself. Here's my main HTML:

``` html
<!doctype html>
<html>
<head>
    <script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/dropbox.js/0.10.2/dropbox.min.js"></script>
    <script src="./NWAuthDriver.js"></script>
</head>
<body>
    <script>
        var client = new Dropbox.Client({ key: '<REDACTED>' });
        client.authDriver(new Dropbox.AuthDriver.NWAuthDriver());

        client.authenticate(function (error) {
            console.log('Authenticated.');
            client.getAccountInfo(function (error, info) {
                console.log(JSON.stringify(info));
            });
        });
    </script>
</body>
</html>
```

maybe it helps someone else, 
i build a Promise Wrapper for dropbox.js that uses a modified Version of dropbox.js (including this Patch) to enable compatibility with Browserify.

https://www.npmjs.com/package/drbx-js

``` coffee-script
Dropbox = require("dropbox")
Promise = require("bluebird")

module.exports =

class DropboxApi
    constructor: (token) ->
        @client = Promise.promisifyAll new Dropbox.Client { token }

    readDir: (tail = { changes: [] }) =>
        @client.deltaAsync(tail.cursorTag)
            .catch (e) => throw "Error reading the remote directory /."
            .then (delta) =>
                delta.changes = tail.changes.concat delta.changes

                if delta.shouldPullAgain
                    @readDir delta
                else delta
```

Usage:

``` coffee-script
new DropboxApi("A token").readDir().then (entries) =>
  console.log entries
```

@sashaperigo @ngalluzzo If you're using webpack, you can include the library from the CDN in your HTML template, and include 'Dropbox' in the `externals` config.

**example.html**

```
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <title>example</title>
    <script src="//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/dropbox.js/0.10.2/dropbox.min.js"></script>
  </head>
```

**webpack.config.js**

```
module.exports = {

  externals: {
    'dropbox' : 'Dropbox'
  },

};
```

Then require the library when you need to use it.

**app.js**

```
var Dropbox = require("dropbox");
new Dropbox.Client({ key: "key" }).authenticate(...)
```

Webpack Externals
https://webpack.github.io/docs/library-and-externals.html

I know this is old but you can't simply replace `window.localStorage` with `chrome.storage.local`.

`window.localStorage` is sync and `chrome.storage.local` is async (needs a callback).

https://developer.chrome.com/apps/storage

It would work for writing, but not for reading.

@saularis You're using [the old dropbox-js library](https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-js), which uses [the retired API v1](https://blogs.dropbox.com/developers/2016/06/api-v1-deprecated/). This library is no longer supported, and API calls made using it won't work anyway, since the API is retired.

Please use [the new dropbox-sdk-js library](https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-sdk-js) instead, which uses API v2.

There's an example using of a download-style call in Node here:

https://github.com/dropbox/dropbox-sdk-js/blob/master/examples/javascript/node/download.js#L19

You don't directly supply a local file path for the resulting file data in the SDK method argument. Instead, the callback gives you the file data, which you can use as desired. (E.g., save it to a file using `fs.writeFile`, as shown in this example.)
